Tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) is a widely used brominated flame retardant. It is harmful and persistent in the environment, and therefore the removal of this brominated flame retardant from plastic waste has drawn attention. Catalytic conversion and debromination of TBBPA offer a viable method for reducing the amount of harmful substances entering plastic recycling processes. In this work, different transition metal catalysts were studied, and their activity was evaluated for decomposition and debromination of TBBPA. The catalytic reactions were conducted in a batch-type autoclave reactor under reductive conditions. Ni/Al2O3 catalysts resulted in the highest conversions, but Ni/TiO2 catalysts produced more completely debrominated products, despite the catalyst being poisoned by bromine. In reactions involving alumina, the support likely acted as a halogen sink, protecting the nickel from direct deactivation. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analysis of the reaction products suggested a possible scheme for TBBPA debromination and decomposition pathways. The main reaction paths for TBBPA debromination involved either step-by-step debromination or the debromination of compounds formed after TBBPA decomposed into two monophenol products. A notable amount of benzyl toluene was produced as a side reaction product from the toluene solvent. Overall, the results indicated that Ni/Al2O3 catalysts offer a promising option for the effective decomposition of TBBPA. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Brominated flame retardant (BFR) Tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) Debromination Supported transition metal catalysts Reaction path Abbreviations BFR brominated flame retardant TBBPA tetrabromobisphenol A POP persistent organic pollutant WEEE waste electric and electronic equipment IWI incipient wetness impregnation SEA strong electrostatic adsorption SEAE strong electrostatic adsorption by evaporation PZC point of zero charge BET Brunauer-Emmett-Teller BJH Barrett-Joyner-Halenda PXRD powder X-ray diffraction SEM scanning electron microscopy EDS energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy TEM transmission electron microscopy XPS X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy AAS atomic absorption spectrometry GC gas chromatography MS mass spectrometry FID flame ionization detector DFT density functional theory Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Continuously growing use of plastics is causing emerging environmental problems, and plastic waste is suggested as one of the geological indicators of the so-called Anthropocene era. Due to its ubiquitous nature, plastic is now present in most terrestrial and marine environments leading to a near-permanent contamination and serious environmental problems [1,2]. Plastic products contain many additives, which are added to the polymer to enhance durability, stability, and functionality of the material. Most commonly used additives are lubricants, stabilizers, pigments, plasticizers, and flame retardants [3], which are compounds designed to inhibit combustion and propagation of fire. Many of these compounds are halogenated, and some have also been listed as persistent organic pollutants (POPs). Due to their possible toxicity to humans and the environment, their use in consumer products is regulated by the Stockholm convention [4]. Legacy brominated flame retardants, which include polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs), hexabromocyclododecane (HBCD), and tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA), have gradually been phased-out, enabling the utilization of novel brominated flame retardants (BFR) [5,6]. Novel brominated flame retardants are designed to replace the banned formulations, and they are typically defined as those that are recently identified in the environment or new to the market [7]. However, legacy BFRs are still commonly encountered in plastic waste. Halogenated flame retardants can be classified as reactive or additive materials depending on the way these compounds were mixed with the plastic material. Reactive flame retardants are chemically bonded to the material, whereas additive flame retardants are often applied on top of the surface, and they are not covalently bonded. Therefore, additive flame retardants can easily leach into the environment [8]. Tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) is the most used brominated flame retardant [9]. The persistent nature and lipophilicity of TBBPA have resulted in the presence of this toxic compound in soil, sediment, and wastewater as well as in human plasma serum and breast milk. TBBPA is also considered as a potential endocrine disruptor as the chemical structure of TBBPA resembles thyroxine hormone [9,10], and the binding affinity to anti-thyroxine antibody is almost as high as in natural ligands [11]. Nearly half of the produced plastics end up in landfills worldwide, even though this wasted material has potential to be used as a feedstock for value added products [12]. Chemical upcycling, also known as valorization, is a method where plastic waste materials are converted into value added products. It relies on chemicals, catalysts, and heat to break down the polymer structure with the main problem in effective valorization being shortage of clean materials [13]. However, various chemical recycling techniques have been developed to treat waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) plastic, and the quality of the products derived from waste plastic has been improved [14]. WEEE is one of the fastest growing waste streams in the world, reaching the total production of 54 million tons in 2019, and predicting the production to reach 75 million tons by 2030 [15]. Since WEEE contain several valuable materials, which can be recovered and reused, it is important to find viable recycling methods, but the hazardous and toxic compounds in WEEE, such as heavy metals and brominated flame retardants, bring a challenge for the recycling processes [14,16]. WEEE plastics were previously treated with landfilling and incineration, but formation of highly toxic compounds, such as dibenzo-p-dioxins and benzofurans, during the thermal treatment raised a demand for more environmentally viable recycling methods [12,14,17]. In WEEE, the amount of brominated flame retardants has been estimated to be up to 25 % of the WEEE plastic [18], from which TBBPA covers nearly 60 % of the total BFRs used [14]. The statement of the European Directive (2012/19/EU) declares that all separately collected WEEE plastic must be free from plastics containing BFRs [18,19]. Effective catalytic debromination of TBBPA was previously demonstrated using supported noble metal catalysts [10,20] and bimetallic catalysts [21]. Additionally, different metal oxides (ZnO, Fe2O3, CaO) and calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2) have demonstrated their debromination efficiency in thermal treatment of printed circuit boards [22,23]. Nickel as a catalyst instead of noble metals has many advantages: nickel can be used in many catalytic reactions and it has high catalytic activity, it is easily available, material and significantly less expensive than comparable noble metals [24]. Production of noble metals, such as platinum group elements Pd, Pt, and Rh, has also the highest global warming potentials per kilogram (kg CO2-eq/kg) [25]. Shortcomings in nickel catalysts are their toxicity and possible carcinogenicity [24]. These issues can be mitigated by lowering the amount of used nickel. Another transition metal that meets the criteria of being inexpensive and easily accessible material is copper. Copper catalysts have been utilized in debromination studies involving the pyrolysis of waste printed circuit boards [26] and in photocatalytic debromination reactions [27]. In this study, TiO₂ and Al₂O₃ supported transition metal catalysts were studied in catalytic conversion of TBBPA. The reactions were carried out in a batch-type autoclave reactor under hydrogen atmosphere and using toluene as a solvent. The main focus of this study was to investigate the activity of prepared supported transition metal catalysts in TBBPA decomposition and to examine the reaction pathways involved in this process. High-resolution mass spectrometry was used to analyze the reaction products, and a possible reaction scheme was proposed based on the findings. Experimentally observed compounds from catalytic decomposition of TBBPA were compared to a literature survey of density functional theory (DFT) calculations of thermal degradation and decomposition of TBBPA in different conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The following materials were purchased from Thermo Fisher Scientific: Titanium(IV) oxide (TiO2) (CAS: 1317–70–0) catalyst support 1/8″ pellets; Nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2 · 6 H2O) (CAS: 13,478–00–7), 99 %; Tetrabromobisphenol A (CAS: 79–94–7), 97 %. Alumina spheres, 1.8/210 (Al2O3) catalyst support, was provided by Sasol. The following materials were purchased from Sigma Aldrich: Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2 · 3 H2O) (CAS: 10,031–43–3), puriss. p.a., 99–104 %; Ni standard solution for AAS (Ni(NO3)2 in HNO3, 0.5 mol/l); 1,4-dibromobenzene (98 %) (CAS: 106–37–6). NH4OH 25 % (CAS: 1336–21–6) for pH adjustment was obtained from Merck. Toluene ≥99.8 % (CAS: 108–88–3); NaNO3 (CAS:7631–99–4), HCl 37 % (CAS: 7647–01–0) and HNO3 69 % (CAS: 7697–37–2) for pH adjustment and Cu standard solution for AAS (Cu(NO3)2 in 2 % HNO3) were purchased from VWR Chemicals, whereas bromine (99+%) was obtained from Acros Organics. All chemicals were used without any purification except toluene, which was dried over activated 4 Å molecular sieves before use. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Supported nickel or copper catalysts were prepared using three different methods, namely incipient wetness impregnation (IWI), strong electrostatic adsorption (SEA), and strong electrostatic adsorption by evaporation (SEAE). Al2O3 and TiO2 were used as support materials and sieved to 200–400 μm particle size. Support materials were calcined in the Muffle furnace before use (550 °C, 5 h, 5 °C/min for Al2O3 and 450 °C, 5 h, 5 °C/min for TiO2). In IWI method, the pore volumes of used support materials were first determined experimentally by the following method: 1 g of support material was weighed into a 50 ml Erlenmeyer flask, into which water was added dropwise using a Pasteur pipette. The flask was shaken, and the support material was weighed after every water addition. The process was stopped before any lumps were forming. This method was used to empirically determine the volume of liquid required to completely fill the pores. The precise total pore volume (cm3/g) of the support was determined by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda method as described later in Section 2.3.1. On surface area analysis. In the IWI method, the metal precursors were dissolved in deionized water followed by combination with the support material. Catalysts were stirred at a room temperature first by hand and then by a platform shaker for two hours after the impregnation. Catalysts were dried in an oven (100 °C) under stagnant air overnight. Two approaches were used to prepare catalysts by using the SEA method: the traditional SEA method with filtration and washing was compared to a method involving evaporation of the liquid, denoted as SEAE. In the SEA method, the pH of the impregnating solution was adjusted above the point of zero charge (PZC) of the support material. The PZC of the support material was first determined by salt addition method as reported in literature [28–30], and pH of the impregnating solution was changed accordingly. Briefly, this method involved preparation of 0.1 M NaNO₃ solution, with the pH adjusted to a range of 2 to 11 by using either HNO₃ or NaOH. The initial pH was measured, and the support material was added into the solution. After 24 h, the final pH was recorded and the difference between the initial and final pH (ΔpH) was plotted against the initial pH value. The PZC of the support material was determined as the point, where the ΔpH was zero. In the SEA method, the active metal complex was formed during the pH change of the impregnating solution. After the pH was adjusted above the PZC value, the metal precursor solution was combined with the support material that was stirred for 24 h in a rotary evaporator in a mild water bath (50 °C). After 24 h stirring, the solid part was filtered and washed with deionized water followed by an oven (50 °C) drying in stagnant air overnight. One batch of SEA catalyst was also prepared by evaporating the liquid using a rotary evaporator. In this SEAE approach, the catalyst was stirred for 24 h, followed by evaporation of the liquid. After evaporation, the catalyst was first dried in a rotary evaporator under vacuum, and the temperature of the water bath was kept at 50 °C. The catalyst was subsequently dried in an oven at 100 °C under stagnant air overnight. The aim of the SEAE method was to keep the metal content of the catalyst higher compared to the filtrated version. All catalysts were calcined in a tube furnace (450 °C) in technical air (Woikoski) and after the calcination, pre-reduced with a continuous formier flow (Formier 5: 5 % H2 in N2, Woikoski) in a tube furnace and stored in a desiccator under nitrogen. The catalysts were sieved to particle sizes of 100–200 μm and 200–400 μm, and the larger particle size was used in catalytic experiments. The prepared catalysts with their properties are presented in Table 1 , and the labels identified in Table 1 are used throughout the article. 2.3 Catalyst characterization 2.3.1 Surface area analysis The catalyst surface area and pore volume were analyzed using a BELSORP MAX X automatic gas adsorption measurement device. The specific surface area (m2/g) was determined by using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, whereas the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was used for calculating the total pore volume (cm3/g). Before the actual measurements, samples were degassed using the BELPREP VAC II. Samples (100–200 mg) were weighed into sample tubes, which were then slowly evacuated to create a vacuum. Once evacuated, the tubes were transferred to the heating section of the device, preheated to 350 °C. The samples were kept at this temperature for three hours. 2.3.2 Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) PXRD data of catalyst powders were measured using a Bruker Advance D8 powder diffractometer, where the used measurement geometry was Bragg-Brentano. The following parameters were used: Cu K α radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å), measurement range (2θ) of 5.0–90.0° with an angle step of 0.05° and scan speed of 10 s. Reduced samples were fixed onto an in-house-built XRD-plate and protected with a Mylar film. The samples were prepared in a glow box filled with nitrogen and covered with a Mylar film in order to avoid oxidation. The reacted catalysts were fixed onto a single-crystal silicon sample holder for measurements. 2.3.3 Scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) SEM imaging was used for morphology and SEM-EDS mode for metal distribution analysis. Morphology analysis was carried out using a Hitachi S-4800 SEM with 10.0 kV accelerating voltage and working distance of 8 mm, whereas the metal distribution analysis was carried out using an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer Noran System Six EDS-detector with 10.0 kV accelerating voltage and working distance of 15 mm. The samples were fixed on a sample holder by carbon tape. Reduced samples were prepared in a glove box filled with nitrogen and samples were transferred quickly into SEM loading chamber to minimize oxidation. 2.3.4 Transmission electron microscopy and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (TEM-EDS) TEM analysis was used for fine structure evaluation and particle size determination. TEM measurements were performed with JEOL JEM-2200FS by using a 200 kV accelerating voltage. All samples were prepared by crushing the catalyst and mixing it with acetone. 2.3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) XPS was used for analyzing the catalyst surface atoms and to confirm if the catalyst surface was changed in activity experiments. Analysis was carried out using XPS Nexsa G2 system with Al Kα source in a standard lens mode with spot size, step size, pass energy and dwell time being 300 μm, 0.050 eV, 50 eV and 100 ms, respectively. For some measurements etching was used with the following parameters: 180 s etching with Ar clusters of 150 atoms accelerated to 8 000 eV The samples were fixed on a sample holder by carbon tape. Reduced and reacted catalysts were fixed on a sample holder inside a glove box filled with argon before being transferred into the XPS load lock in a vacuum transfer module to protect the samples from oxidation. 2.3.6 Atomic absorption spectrometry (AAS) Metal content of the catalyst was determined by using AAS. The measurement was performed with a SpectrAA 220 atomic absorption spectrometer with acetylene/air flow. The wavelength of Ni lamp was 352.5 nm with a lamp current of 4.0 mA, whereas the wavelength of Cu lamp was 217.9 nm with a lamp current of 4.0 mA. AAS samples were prepared by boiling the catalysts in a dilute HNO3 for two hours. After the metals were dissolved into the acid, they were further diluted with deionized water in volumetric flasks. Nickel stock solution (1 000 mg metal/l in HNO3) and copper stock solution (1 000 mg metal/l in HNO3) were used for calibration standards. 2.4 Activity tests Catalytic activity was examined in catalytic debromination reaction, where TBBPA was used as a model compound. Before the catalytic reaction, the catalysts were pre-reduced in a tube furnace (450 °C, 3 h) with formier (5 % H₂ in N₂). The pre-reduced catalyst powder (200–400 μm) was placed into an autoclave, which was subsequently sealed and flushed several times with N2. Before the reaction, the catalysts were reduced in an autoclave under conditions of 210 °C (the practical upper temperature limit of the Teflon liner) and 40 bar H2 for 2 h This was to ensure that the active component was in a metallic state. Subsequently, 0.298 g of TBBPA was dissolved in 70 ml of toluene resulting in a bromine content of 2 500 ppm (μg/ml). The resulting mixture was then transferred into a feed-vessel by glass syringe, and purged with N₂ (N50, 99.999 %, Woikoski) and H₂ (H50, 99.999 %, Woikoski) before placed into the reactor. The reactions were carried out in a Teflon-lined autoclave reactor (volume of 110 ml) equipped with an overhead stirrer with three bladed propeller (rotating at 1 000 rpm) under a hydrogen atmosphere (80 bar H₂) and 210 °C temperature. The high hydrogen pressure was used to ensure reductive conditions despite the high liquid volume. The overall reaction time was set to four hours and samples (approximately 1 ml) were withdrawn every hour through a sampling tube. Diffusion limits were tested with catalysts having different particle sizes together with different stirring speeds. The diffusion tests were conducted with 5 %Ni/Al2O3-SEAE catalyst. A smaller particle size of 100–200 μm exhibited TBBPA conversion within 6 % relative to 200–400 μm. Moreover, the increased stirring speeds of 1 200 rpm did not induce a noticeable effect on the conversion. At the end of the reaction, the stirring was seized, and the autoclave was rapidly cooled down in an ice bath. The reaction solution and the used catalyst were stored in sealed sample tubes for further analysis. 2.5 Product analytics The reaction products were analyzed using a Bruker 456GC gas chromatograph (GC) connected to a high-resolution time-of-flight mass spectrometer (Bruker timsTOF; Bremen, Germany). The GC system was also equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID), enabling simultaneous analysis with the mass spectrometry (MS). The measurements were conducted by a split injection method (15:1). After a 3 min hold at 60 °C, the oven was heated to 110 °C at 5 °C/min, then to 300 °C at 15 °C/min, with an 8 min final hold. The used injector temperature was 280 °C. The column was Rxi-5Sil MS 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm (Restek, Pa, USA). 1,4-dibromobenzene was used as an internal standard for quantification, and response factors were determined experimentally when applicable. Details on the determination of response factors can be found in Table S1. The reaction products were identified based on their accurate masses/elemental compositions based on the GC–MS data. Further support for the identification was obtained by analyzing fragmentation patterns and by determining Kovats retention indices. Products were quantified by the GC-FID data based on peak areas. The yield was calculated according to Eq. (1), (1) Y product = n product n TBBP A 0 · 100 % where Y product is the yield of a product at certain time point of the reaction, n product is the molar amount of product determined from the GC-FID data and n TBBPA0 is the molar amount of the TBBPA model compound in the unreacted sample at time=0. A stoichiometric correction was used for dissociated products. TBBPA conversion at certain time point was calculated based on Eq. (2), (2) conversion = ( 1 − n TBBP A t n TBBP A 0 ) · 100 % where n TBBPAt is the molar amount of TBBPA at time t based on GC-FID data. The carbon balances were calculated by multiplying the molar amounts of each product by the number of carbon atoms in that compound and comparing this to the number of carbon atoms in the unreacted sample. Gas-phase of the reaction mixture was examined qualitatively by extracting a portion of gas from the batch reactor headspace into a gas cuvette and measuring it using the fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) (Bruker Vertex 70, Bremen, Germany). The cuvette was approximately 16 cm long and equipped with ZnSe windows. The spectrum was collected with 16 scans and a resolution of 4 cm-1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Typically, the preparation of supported metal catalysts targets to a maximal metal surface area, since the catalytic activity of the catalyst is in most cases dependent on the metal particles [31,32]. IWI method was selected for catalyst preparation method due to simplicity and low cost. SEA method was used with expectation of a highly dispersed supported catalyst [33]. However, with filtration and washing steps, the SEA method is more time consuming than the traditional IWI. In addition, SEA method by evaporation (SEAE) was used to combine these two methods. The metal contents of the catalysts were confirmed using AAS and the results are presented in Table 2 . The metal content of catalysts 5 %Ni/TiO2-IWI and 5 %Ni/Al2O3-IWI, was determined to be 4.7 and 4.4 wt-%, respectively. The corresponding copper catalysts, 5 %Cu/TiO2-IWI and 5 %Cu/Al2O3-IWI, had metal contents of 4.8 and 4.7 wt-%, respectively. These were close to the targeted amount of 5.0 wt-%. The higher targeted 10 wt-% content of IWI catalysts 10 %Ni/TiO2-IWI and 10 %Ni/Al2O3-IWI had an actual metal amount of 9.2 and 9.1 wt-%, respectively. The SEAE catalysts, 5 %Cu/TiO2-SEAE and 5 %Cu/Al2O3-SEAE, had an actual metal amount of 4.5 and 4.8 wt-%, respectively. The corresponding nickel catalysts, 5 %Ni/TiO2-SEAE and 5 %Ni/Al2O3-SEAE, had metal amounts of 4.4 and 4.6 wt-%, respectively. In contrast, the corresponding SEA catalysts 5 %Ni/TiO2-SEA and 5 %Ni/Al2O3-SEA had only a metal content of 1.0 and 3.0 wt-%, respectively. The lower metal content of SEA catalysts with respect to other studied catalysts aligns well with the preparation method including filtering and washing steps before calcination. BET surface area analysis confirmed the expected differences between the support materials. The measured surface areas for all catalysts used in catalytic experiments are listed in Table 2. PXRD analysis showed some differences between the preparation methods and the support materials. Fig. 1 shows PXRD diffractograms of reduced nickel catalysts with different support materials, as well as pure supports in their oxidized forms. PXRD diffractograms of nickel catalysts in their oxidized forms (Fig. S2) and PXRD diffractograms of copper catalysts in their reduced forms (Fig. S3) are presented in Supplementary material. Ni/TiO2 catalysts prepared with IWI or SEAE method indicated metallic nickel in their PXRD diffractograms. Such metallic Ni reflections can appear on PXRD diffractogram due to uneven distribution of nickel or larger metal clusters on support surface. This was anticipated with a relatively low surface area of TiO2 and sufficiently high metal loadings (5 wt-% or 10 wt-%) of the catalysts. In comparison, noble metal catalysts typically have lower loadings of approximately 1 wt-%. In TiO2 supported catalyst the areal number densities (atom/nm2) [34] are higher than in corresponding Al2O3 catalyst, except in SEA catalysts. This relatively high numerical value of atoms per surface area explains the observed agglomeration of active metal in TiO2 supported catalysts (Table 2). As expected for Ni/TiO2 catalyst prepared with SEA method (with filtering and washing), the distribution of metal particles was more even than in IWI, and no clear agglomeration was detected, since metallic Ni reflections were not visible in PXRD, indicating that filtering and washing removed the excess metals. Agglomeration was not detected in alumina supported catalysts prepared by any method in PXRD diffractograms, where only reflections corresponding to alumina were observed. This observation aligns well with the higher surface areas of the support as evidenced by the BET results. SEM-EDS analysis revealed no significant differences between the preparation methods. According to the EDS mapping, no significant nickel or copper agglomerates were observed on any catalyst surface. The metal particles were rather evenly distributed both for TiO2 and Al2O3 supported catalysts. SEM-EDS images of supported nickel and copper catalysts are presented in Supplementary material (Figs. S4, S5). Fig. 2 shows TEM images together with nickel EDS maps of Ni/TiO2 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared with IWI and SEA methods. It was apparent that nickel particles were not distinguishable from the support material solely by TEM imaging, because the difference in atomic numbers between the support materials (ZTi = 22, ZAl = 13) and metal (ZNi = 28) was relatively small. Hence, EDS was used to indicate nickel particles. A statistical analysis of metal particle size was not conducted due to the heavy time-consuming nature of the EDS measurements. Therefore, the size of the metal particles was analyzed qualitatively. According to TEM-EDS results, the metal particle size was in the range of 3–5 nm. Metal agglomerates were clearly visible in catalysts by the IWI method, whereas SEA catalysts showed fewer agglomerates with evenly distributed metal particles on top of the support surface. The TEM-EDS results align with the PXRD data, where metallic nickel reflections were visible in Ni/TiO2 catalysts, except the one prepared with SEA method. Filtration and washing steps in the SEA preparation method removed the excess metal, and only tightly bound small nanoparticles remained on the support surface. XPS measurements showed the characteristic spectra for TiO2 and Al2O3 supported nickel catalysts. The Ni2p spectra of Ni/TiO2 catalyst showed clear differences between the oxidized and reduced catalysts. The experimental binding energy values for metallic and oxidized nickel were at 852.13 eV and 855.44 eV, respectively. These experimental binding energy values were close to the corresponding literature values of 852.54 eV and 853.78 eV, respectively [35,36]. The XPS spectra of Ni/Al2O3 catalysts had minor shifts in binding energy values between the oxidized and reduced samples, however the spectra looked similar. Similar effect has also been detected in literature [37]. The XPS spectra of 5 %Ni/TiO2-IWI, 5 %Ni/Al2O3-IWI and 5 %Ni/Al2O3-SEA in their oxidized and reduced forms (with peak fittings) and overlays of the same spectra are presented in Supplementary material (Figs. S6–S8). 3.2 Activity tests The activity of catalysts for the decomposition of TBBPA was evaluated in batch reactor experiments, with the corresponding conversions presented in Table 2. Control experiments to evaluate thermal conversion and contribution of support materials were performed. The thermal conversion of TBBPA was examined in the absence of a catalyst, resulting in negligible conversion over 4 h of reaction. The effect of the support material was examined in experiments using either Al2O3 or TiO2 as a catalyst without metal dopants. The conversions were approximately 10 % for Al2O3 and 15 % for TiO2. Hence, support materials exhibited some catalytic activity themselves as presented in Fig. S9. After the initial experimentation, it became clear that copper catalysts resulted only in minor TBBPA conversion. Each copper catalyst (5 %Cu/TiO2-IWI, 5 %Cu/Al2O3-IWI, 5 %Cu/Al2O3-SEAE and 5 %Cu/TiO2-SEAE) exhibited below 20 % conversion. Hence, the overall activities of bare Al2O3 and TiO2 were similar to those of copper catalysts, and the activity of copper towards TBBPA conversion can be considered minor (Fig. S9). Therefore, further experiments with copper were discontinued. In turn, the introduction of nickel notably promoted the TBBPA conversion. Especially Ni/Al2O3 presented high conversions relative to bare support material, whereas with Ni/TiO2 catalysts the effect was less pronounced. A more detailed analysis of the progress of the reactions is presented in Fig. 3 , depicting the catalytic reactions employing Ni/TiO2 and Ni/Al2O3 catalyst materials prepared using IWI and SEA methods. The activity experiments were performed at least twice, and error bars (standard error of a sample mean) are presented in the Fig. 3. Stacked plot bars are scaled to 100 % for the sake of clarity. The carbon balance of every experiment was in between 87 and 100 % after four hours of reaction. Complete list of scaled yields and standard errors of sample means are presented in Supplementary material (Table S2). The gas composition of headspace was analyzed occasionally after the reaction using FTIR. Toluene along traces of CO2 and H2O, presumably originating from the atmosphere, were primary components detected. With TiO2 supported catalysts, the rate of TBBPA conversion considerably decreased over the course of the reaction, showing higher activity during the initial two hours of the reaction compared to the last two hours. This behavior implies catalyst deactivation, which is covered in more detail later in the article. Some differences in activity were observed among TiO2 supported catalysts. The 10 %Ni/TiO2-IWI exhibited the highest TBBPA conversion of 50 % (Fig. S10), while other prepared TiO2 catalysts produced somewhat equal conversions of approximately 30 % as seen in Table 2. This indicates that in TiO2 supported catalysts the amount of metal correlates to a higher conversion, and the support material has a less pronounced effect on TBBPA conversion. Al2O3 supported catalysts showed steadily increasing conversions, and no such clear evidence of catalyst deactivation was observed. In Al2O3 supported catalysts, the conversion in every experiment was close to each other (∼55 %−62 %). The nickel loading appeared to play a less crucial role in the activity, as the high-loading 10 %Ni/Al2O3-IWI (9.1 wt-% as per AAS) exhibited practically equal conversion to 5 %Ni/Al2O3-SEA despite having considerably lower effective loading (3.0 wt-% as per AAS). Hence, the preparation method appears to have some influence on the TBBPA conversion efficiency on alumina. The attainment of high conversions with lower nickel loading SEA catalysts suggests the importance of metal-support interaction in determining activity. According to these results, alumina supported nickel catalysts exhibited the highest activity, resulting in the highest TBBPA conversions, while titania supported catalysts produced more fully debrominated products. The product distribution at the initial stages of reaction varied between the two support materials. With TiO2 supported catalysts, phenol was formed already at early stages of the reaction, and it remained as the main reaction product after four hours, based on molar amount. Comparably, with Al2O3 supported catalysts, tribromobisphenol A was formed rapidly at the beginning of the reaction, while phenol formation occurred more gradually. This behavior was observed irrespective of the preparation method and metal loading. Tribromobisphenol A remained the most abundant product in the final sample collected after four hours. Significantly smaller amounts of tribromobisphenol A were observed in Ni/TiO2 catalyzed reactions. The formation of tribromobisphenol A and phenol in TBBPA decomposition with different catalysts are presented in Fig. 4 . Based on these findings, it appears that support materials are directing the debromination reaction into different reaction paths. 3.3 Reaction network The reaction mechanism of TBBPA decomposition in transition metal catalyzed reactions is somewhat unclear. Besides a step-by-step debromination of TBBPA, β-scission, the cleavage between the isopropyl group and the benzene ring [38] were proposed to be an important degradation routes [39]. TBBPA was suggested to undergo different kinds of reactions to produce smaller brominated fragments and also completely debrominated compounds. DFT calculations of thermal decomposition of TBBPA in gas-phase suggested that the reaction can proceed by three different paths: fission of the aromatic C-Br bond, fission of the CCH3 bond followed by the 1,2-H shift from one of the methyl group to carbon, and scission of isopropylidene bond (β-scission), which can either be a direct fission or fission followed by H migration from CH3 group [40]. Scheme 1 presents a possible pathway for TBBPA debromination and decomposition based on our experiments. The compounds presented in Scheme 1 were detected by GC–MS from samples, which were extracted from the reactor. Details of the product identification are presented in Table S3 and Table S4. Similar reactions and compounds have also been proposed by the DFT calculations [40–42] and some have been observed in photolytic decomposition reaction of TBBPA [39]. The reaction path on blue background in Scheme 1 presents TBBPA debromination that proceeds by fission of the aromatic C-Br bond. In this step-by-step debromination, the bromine atoms in TBBPA are replaced with hydrogen one by one. This debromination path does not break the bisphenol structure. The strong formation of tribromobisphenol A suggests that this reaction pathway is initially favored on Al2O3 supported Ni catalysts (Fig. 3). It could be anticipated that the final product in this pathway would be bisphenol A. However, the species was not detected by the GC–MS. The proceeding of reaction route was further evaluated by performing a debromination experiment for self-synthesized bromobisphenol A with a 5 %Ni/Al2O3-IWI as a catalyst [43]. After four hours of reaction, phenolic C9 compounds and phenol were observed, indicating that bromobisphenol A underwent fission of the isopropylidene bond, resulting in the production of phenol as a final product. Another possible reaction route involves TBBPA undergoing a decomposition into two monophenolic products, which are then debrominated. Scheme 1 presents this decomposition reaction together with the following debromination steps. Fission followed by H migration (green background) forms directly 2,6-dibromo-4-isopropenylphenol and 2,6-dibromophenol. Consequent debromination steps eventually lead to formation of 2‑bromo-4-isopropenylphenol or phenol. The third reaction route involves breaking of the bisphenolic structure by direct fission (red background), which forms different products; reaction of these radical compounds resulted in a formation of 2,6-dibromo-4-isopropylphenol and 2,6-dibromophenol and finally leading to formation of 4-isopropylphenol and phenol after debromination steps. Based on the observed strong phenol formation, TiO2 supported Ni catalysts seem favor these reaction routes. While the breaking of the bisphenol structure in Scheme 1 is presented for TBBPA, it is reasonable to expect similar reactions for other double-ring compounds as demonstrated with bromobisphenol A experiment. It is even plausible that compounds with one completely debrominated phenol group can more readily coordinate themselves onto the catalyst surface compared to the corresponding bulkier brominated configurations. This could facilitate the more accessible breaking of the bisphenol structure. Moreover, the predominance of tribromobisphenol A as the primary reaction product on Ni/Al2O3 catalysts even after four hours, implies the presence of a rate-limiting step in this reaction pathway. This would explain why phenol begins to form gradually after the strong initial formation of tribromobisphenol A. Additional investigation through DFT could offer deeper insight into the underlying mechanism. The GC–MS data also revealed the presence of notable amount of three C14H14 isomers, with the structure including two phenyl groups. The product was found also in the thermal control experiment. In principle, these products could form through bisphenol A, although hydrodeoxygenation of phenol requires rather extreme conditions [44]. However, bisphenol A was not detected by MS in any of the reactions, implying that C14H14 compounds are side reaction products of toluene solvent. Previous literature mentions formation of benzyl toluene (C14H14) in a reaction between toluene, bromine and a possible catalyst [45]. The reaction was proposed to proceed via alkylation of toluene by benzyl bromide. Consequently, we performed a confirmation experiment by introducing a 5 %Ni/Al2O3-IWI catalyst, toluene and elemental bromine in a batch reactor under same reaction conditions as other experiments. The molar amount of bromine was approximately the same as in TBBPA experiments (120 µl). Significant formation of C14H14 together with some lesser amount C21H20 and C10H12 was observed, effectively confirming that these products are not part of the reaction network related to TBBPA decomposition. Furthermore, C7H7Br compound was detected by MS, implying the presence of the reactive species, benzyl bromide. The corresponding experiment in toluene without bromine yielded only a minimal amount of above-mentioned compounds. Side product formation from solvent is worth taking into the consideration in production of aromatic chemicals through chemical recycling, where waste plastic feedstock may include substantial amounts of bromine. Further analysis revealed that toluene appears to react also with TBBPA decomposition products. GC–MS data indicates presence of C16H16Br2O and C16H17BrO. Several isomers were observed, and one possible structure is presented in Scheme 1. Based on the observed reactivity of toluene, it is possible that toluene reacts with C9 compounds in Scheme 1. However, according to GC-FID data the amount of these compounds was minor, especially in the case of C16H17BrO and, hence, it was not included in the yield calculations in Fig. 3. 3.4 Catalyst deactivation The reacted nickel catalysts were analyzed with AAS, PXRD, and XPS, and copper catalysts with AAS, in order to confirm the possible changes in the catalyst composition or structure due to the reaction. AAS confirmed that the metal content of the used catalysts were systematically lower than for the unreacted catalysts (Table 2). With copper catalysts the effect was more pronounced, which also explains the lower activity compared to nickel catalysts. This indicated that some of the metal leached out during the reaction. However, it is likely not the only reason for catalyst deactivation, as halogens, such as bromine, are known to bind on the active site of the metal, thereby poisoning the catalyst [46]. In PXRD, reflections of the support materials were detected. Some unidentified reflections in TiO2, Al2O3 and 5 %Ni/TiO2-IWI diffractograms were also visible at 15.2° in 5 %Ni/TiO2-IWI and 18.2° in TiO2 and Al2O3. The PXRD diffractograms of used catalysts are presented in Supplementary material (Fig. S11). Fig. S12 presents diffractograms of empty sample holder and TBBPA for reference, indicating that the unknown peaks do not originate from these two sources. In Fig. 3, Ni/TiO2 catalysts showed higher activity during the initial two hours of the reaction compared to the last two hours, suggesting a deactivation of a catalyst. Furthermore, the observation that the higher nickel loading correlated with higher TBBPA conversion on TiO2 catalysts implies that bromine binds selectively to nickel rather than TiO2. This could explain why it took longer for 10 %Ni/TiO2-IWI catalyst to become completely poisoned by bromine compared to TiO2 catalysts with lower metal loading. After the bromine has poisoned nickel, TiO2 may assume primary responsibility for catalytic activity, as it has demonstrated some efficacy in TBBPA conversion (Fig. S9). XPS was used to confirm the possible halogen poisoning of the used catalysts. The measurements revealed that nickel bromide was formed during the debromination reaction. In Ni2p spectra, the signals of nickel shifted to higher binding energies in the reacted sample, indicating some electronegative atom binding to nickel. Literature value for nickel bromide is 855.2 eV [36] while experimental value for the same signal was 855.74 eV As a confirmation for NiBr2 spectrum, a similar result was found in literature [36]. Fig. 5 represents the experimental Ni2p XPS spectra of reacted 5 %Ni/TiO2-IWI catalyst. Regarding Al2O3 supported catalysts, the nickel loading did not appear to significantly influence TBBPA conversion, as demonstrated by the similar conversions achieved with low metal loading 5 %Ni/Al2O3-SEA catalyst and higher metal loading 10 %Ni/Al2O3-IWI. This could be explained by a scenario in which alumina support is able to adsorb bromine, protecting nickel from poisoning. The formation of aluminium bromide has previously been reported [47]. Hence, Ni/Al2O3 catalysts remained active longer, as evidenced by higher conversions relative to Ni/TiO2 catalysts. XPS analysis was also carried out for alumina supported catalysts. Although nickel bromide was detected, no clear deactivation similar to Ni/TiO2 catalysts was confirmed after four hours of reaction. Alumina supported transition metal catalysts tolerated halogen poisoning better than titania supported transition metal catalysts. No clear shifts in binding energies were observed in other measurements indicating that bromine was only attached to nickel. The extent of catalyst deactivation was tested with 5 %Ni/Al2O3-IWI catalyst in similar reaction conditions as the other catalytic experiments. The catalyst was reduced normally before the first reaction. After the first experiment, the reaction liquid was extracted, and the catalyst was washed with toluene and dried in an oven at 50 °C. The autoclave including catalyst was subsequently attached back to the top of the reactor, the reactor was purged with N2, and left under nitrogen atmosphere. Before the next experiment, the catalyst was reduced with hydrogen (210 °C, 40 bar H2, 2 h). In Fig. 6 , the progress of two consecutive reactions is presented. Comparing the reactions, it can be concluded that the activity of the catalyst significantly decreased after the first experiment. The extent of deactivation in Fig. 6(b) is surprisingly pronounced compared to the initial reaction depicted in Fig. 6(a), where TBBPA conversion continued to increase throughout the experiment. While some of the activity decrease may be attributed to the loss of catalyst particles in preparation of the second batch experiment, the deactivation remains evident. Despite the nickel catalyst presenting activity in TBBPA decomposition, the future catalyst development needs to address concerns related to the catalyst deactivation during these reactions. 4 Conclusions The catalytic activity of supported nickel catalysts was demonstrated in a batch-type autoclave reactor. The catalytic conversion of TBBPA was conducted under reductive atmosphere in 210 °C and 80 bar H2. The catalysts were prepared by three different methods: incipient wetness impregnation, strong electrostatic adsorption by evaporation and strong electrostatic adsorption. Based on the catalytic experiments, the activity of the catalysts was strongly dependent on the metal-support material combination. The activity of Ni/TiO2 catalysts correlated with metal loading and produced more completely debrominated products. The TiO2 supported nickel catalysts favored the formation of phenols in debromination reactions. Loading-activity-relation implied selective halogen poisoning of nickel, which was confirmed by XPS. Ni/Al2O3 catalysts displayed the highest conversions, and activity did not correlate with metal loading. This could indicate that Al2O3 may act as a halogen sink, underlining the importance of metal-support interaction in maintaining activity. Even though Ni/Al2O3 catalysts seemed to tolerate the halogen poisoning, the activity of the catalyst decreased significantly after one experiment. Ni/Al2O3 catalysts produced significant amount of tribromobisphenol A compared to TiO2 supported catalysts, indicating preference for different reaction paths between these catalysts. Three possible reaction paths of TBBPA decomposition were proposed based on the identified reaction products. In this scheme, decomposition can take place through a step-by-step debromination, resulting in the formation of tri, di and bromobisphenol A (C15H15BrO2). Alternatively, brominated bisphenol A structures can undergo direct fission or fission with H-migration of the isopropylidene group. In direct fission, the final products were 4-isopropylphenol and phenol, whereas in fission with hydrogen migration the final products were 2‑bromo-4-isopropylphenol and phenol. A notable amount of benzyl toluene (C14H14) was formed during the reaction, which was confirmed to be a side reaction product of toluene solvent. The reactivity of toluene solvent is worth to take into consideration when producing aromatic chemicals through chemical recycling, since waste plastic feedstock may contain significant amount of bromine. It is anticipated that effective debromination of toxic brominated flame retardants will become increasingly important for promoting plastic recycling processes in the near future, thereby supporting green transition and sustainable development. Decomposition of TBBPA is a complex reaction, and the exact reaction mechanism on catalyst surface is difficult to confirm without computational chemistry. We plan to return to this issue in a future communication. CRediT authorship contribution statement E. coredata.dc:description: Tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) is a widely used brominated flame retardant. It is harmful and persistent in the environment, and therefore the removal of this brominated flame retardant from plastic waste has drawn attention. Catalytic conversion and debromination of TBBPA offer a viable method for reducing the amount of harmful substances entering plastic recycling processes. In this work, different transition metal catalysts were studied, and their activity was evaluated for decomposition and debromination of TBBPA. The catalytic reactions were conducted in a batch-type autoclave reactor under reductive conditions. Ni/Al2O3 catalysts resulted in the highest conversions, but Ni/TiO2 catalysts produced more completely debrominated products, despite the catalyst being poisoned by bromine. In reactions involving alumina, the support likely acted as a halogen sink, protecting the nickel from direct deactivation. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analysis of the reaction products suggested a possible scheme for TBBPA debromination and decomposition pathways. The main reaction paths for TBBPA debromination involved either step-by-step debromination or the debromination of compounds formed after TBBPA decomposed into two monophenol products. A notable amount of benzyl toluene was produced as a side reaction product from the toluene solvent. Overall, the results indicated that Ni/Al2O3 catalysts offer a promising option for the effective decomposition of TBBPA.
